author: Ruben Hassid
author_headline: Master AI before it masters you.
text:
I test OpenAI's 'ğ—¦ğ—¼ğ—¿ğ—®' vs. the new Google 'ğ—©ğ—²ğ—¼-ğŸ¯'.

I feel like comparing a ğ—¯ğ—¶ğ—¸ğ—² vs. a ğ—¿ğ—¼ğ—°ğ—¸ğ—²ğ˜:

â†’ ğ—ªğ—µğ—®ğ˜ ğ˜†ğ—¼ğ˜‚ ğ—°ğ—®ğ—» ğ˜€ğ—²ğ—² ğ—¼ğ—» ğ˜ğ—µğ—² ğ—¿ğ—¶ğ—´ğ—µğ˜

I generated videos, just from text, using Sora.

It's the most hyped AI video generator from OpenAI.

And the results are glitchy. No sound. It's old news.

â†’ ğ—ªğ—µğ—®ğ˜ ğ˜†ğ—¼ğ˜‚ ğ—°ğ—®ğ—» ğ˜€ğ—²ğ—² ğ—¼ğ—» ğ˜ğ—µğ—² ğ—¹ğ—²ğ—³ğ˜

This is the new model from Google: Veo-3.

It's not live yet, but I took their selected examples.

As you can see, the results are fascinating:

â˜‘ï¸ Little to no glitch
â˜‘ï¸ Ultra-realistic physics
â˜‘ï¸ Complex camera motion
â˜‘ï¸ Multiple characters with vibrant emotions
â˜‘ï¸ Sound included. Even for lip-synced dialogues

â†’ ğ—ªğ—µğ—®ğ˜'ğ˜€ ğ—ºğ˜† ğ—°ğ—¼ğ—»ğ—°ğ—¹ğ˜‚ğ˜€ğ—¶ğ—¼ğ—»?

5 months ago, I said 2025 was the year of AI videos.

And here we are:

It's no longer funny.
It's no longer a meme. 
It's the "ChatGPT" moment of AI videos. 

â†³ But it's not coming from OpenAI, but Google.
